node.text:
While the "15-minute city" model promotes neighborhood-level urban planning, Sweden is pursuing a hyper-local twist: a scheme to redesign every street in the nation.

For more, read the report by @citylab: bloomberg.com/citylab/design

node.text:
Two of the world's wealthiest individuals will attempt to fly into space just nine days apart.

Here's how their space trips compare. (via @quicktake)

node.title: Billionaire Space Race: Branson vs. Bezos

node.text: The sudden cancellation of Ant Group’s IPO shocked investors, but Beijing's slapdown of Jack Ma was years in the making. And Alibaba and Ant aren't the only tech firms under scrutiny by Chinese regulators.

node.title: How China Lost Patience With Its Loudest Billionaire

node.text:
Plant-based meat used to mean burgers and sausages. Not anymore.

Using techniques from 3D printing to specially cultivated mushrooms, these companies are at the forefront of the next generation of alternative meats: whole cuts. (via @quicktake)

node.text:
Taiwan is becoming a bigger issue between the world's two biggest superpowers. Taipei — a U.S. ally — and Beijing have avoided war for more than seven decades, but that balance is getting harder to maintain as China becomes more assertive in its desire for reunification.

Watch the full video at the link in bio to understand why analysts say Taiwan's status is "the most likely issue to draw China and the U.S. into a direct military conflict."

node.title: Why the Biggest U.S.-China Issue Is About Taiwan

node.text: Palladium's surge has given it the title of most expensive of the major traded precious metals, and its gap over gold may be about to widen, reports Nicole Sy. (via @quicktake)

node.title: Palladium: The Most Precious Metal You've Never Heard Of

node.text:
Shotgun houses are as much a hallmark of New Orleans as brass bands or beignets. Here's a short history of these famous U.S. homes built without hallways.

Explore more iconic home designs that shaped global cities in this @citylab series: bloomberg.com/home-design-history

node.title: Inside the History of New Orleans' Shotgun Houses

node.text: Influencers have infiltrated nearly every industry as social media increasingly dictates what we buy and how we buy it. This now includes really big purchases—like an apartment or a house. The real estate business may never be the same.

node.title: Move Over Brokers, Instagram is Turning Real Estate Upside Down

node.text: From your phones to your car, almost everything we use depends on silicon semiconductors, or chips. China is giving the industry the same strategic importance it gave to its atomic bomb program. Here's why. Click the link in bio to see the full video.

node.title: Inside China’s Race for Chip Supremacy

node.text: Lucid Motors is inching closer to production of its debut electric vehicle. CEO Peter Rawlinson took Bloomberg's Ed Ludlow for a ride in the company's latest $169,000 pre-production car, the Air, to discuss why the road ahead is proving so hard.

node.title: Lucid Wants to Take on Tesla With 'Air' Sedan

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on July 24, 2021. May be an image of footwear and text.

node.text:
Switzerland’s On quickly won credibility in the world of runners, not to mention backing from a tennis legend. Now it’s increasingly catching the eye of the wider athleisure-loving public.
 
New data show the sneaker brand is enjoying a steady gain in market share in the U.S., where its distinctive tubular-cushion soles have attracted a cult following. Its association with Roger Federer — including an investment reportedly worth around $54 million — hasn’t hurt either.
 
Insiders say On's next step is an IPO in New York that could value the company as high as $5 billion. Full story at the link in bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business in 432 Park Avenue. May be an image of skyscraper, sky and text that says 'Manhattan penthouse with 96th- floor views goes on sale for $169 million Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Six bedrooms, seven bathrooms and one breathtaking view.
 
The penthouse at the top of Manhattan's 432 Park Ave. has gone on sale for $169 million — almost double what the owner paid for it in 2016.
 
The listing, by broker Ryan Serhant, calls the 96th-floor home "a trophy unlike any other in the world," with a private elevator landing, herringbone white oak floors and designer furniture from Fendi, Bentley and Hermes. See more at the link in bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on July 23, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'ZomatoIPO launches 38-year-old founder in' India's super rich" Bloomberg Vealth'.

node.text:
A strong debut for food-delivery platform Zomato has made founder Deepinder Goyal an instant poster boy for India's fledging startup scene.
 
The company’s shares gained 66% on their first day of trading in Mumbai, pushing Goyal’s fortune close to the $1 billion mark, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index. The listing also sets the stage for a plethora of unicorns to follow with their own IPOs.
 
The 38-year-old first got the idea for the service as a student at the Indian Institute of Technology, where he had a frustrating experience ordering a pizza. Read his story at the link in our bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business in National Stadium (Tokyo). May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'No-spectator ceremony marks start of delayed Tokyo Olympics Bloomberg'.

node.text:
The Olympic opening ceremony kicked off in front of a near-empty National Stadium in Tokyo, marking the official start of a games beset by setbacks and scandals.

Organizers have banned almost all spectators because of concerns about the spread of coronavirus. The whole event was delayed by one year because of the pandemic.

Just 950 special guests, including U.S. First Lady Jill Biden, watched the showcase from inside the stadium, which has a capacity of 68,000. Tap the link in our bio for more on what to expect from an Olympics like no other.

📷: Dylan Martinez - Pool/Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on July 23, 2021. May be an image of money and text.

node.text:
The secretive companies that manage the affairs of the super-rich are increasingly looking to make bets on crypto.

Goldman Sachs found that nearly half the family offices it does business with want to add digital currencies to their stable of investments. Another 15% said they already held them. 

In recent months, family offices have been one of the biggest drivers of the boom in special purpose acquisition companies, or SPACs. For many, crypto looks like the next target. Tap the link in bio for more on how the world’s wealthiest are investing.

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on July 22, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Alonger gap between Pfizer doses boostsantibodies, study says Bloomberg'.

node.text:
An interval of eight to 10 weeks between doses of the Covid-19 vaccine developed by Pfizer and BioNTech boosts the effectiveness of the two-shot regimen compared with a shorter interval, a U.K. study found.

“Eight weeks is probably the sweet spot,” in terms of the trade-off between getting as many people fully vaccinated as quickly as possible and allowing the population to produce higher antibody levels, professor Susanna Dunachie, the study lead from the University of Oxford, said. Link in bio for more.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on July 22, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, drink and text.

node.text:
Second boats full of prostitutes. Cannabis buffets. And don’t forget the caviar.

Getting a job on a megayacht isn't easy. Competition for jobs is fierce, and the pandemic has only strengthened demand for luxury getaways at sea — along with crews that deal with the whims, wishes and indiscretions of wealthy passengers.

The job may sound glamorous. It's not. But — you do see some *things.* Read in full at the link in bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on July 22, 2021. May be an image of 3 people and text that says 'Covid may have claimed as many as 5 million lives in India KELPUP THE PAC Bloomberg'.

node.text:
The actual death toll from Covid-19 in India may be around 5 million, 10 times the number officially recorded by Narendra Modi’s government, experts say.

Multiple studies show India’s virus carnage is vastly underestimated because of a combination of under-counting, administrative delays and a lack of testing, leading to Covid deaths being classified as other conditions like heart disease.

Even the most conservative estimate in a report by the Washington-based Center for Global Development puts the country’s tally at more than double the U.S., the highest recorded in the world so far. Link in bio for more.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on July 22, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, eyeglasses and text that says 'Tokyo Olympics fires opening ceremony director over Holocaustjoke Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Organizers of the Tokyo Olympics fired the director of the opening ceremony a day before it takes place after a decades-old video emerged of him joking about the Holocaust.
 
The scandal involving Kentaro Kobayashi is the latest in a series of PR disasters to hit the games. Olympics chief Seiko Hashimoto said it was unclear how the set piece event, whose guests include French President Emmanuel Macron and U.S. First Lady Jill Biden, would be handled on Friday.

Read more via the link in our bio.

node.text:
China's Henan province is bracing for more heavy rain after severe flooding that left at least 33 dead and sparked large-scale evacuations.

The death toll includes at least 12 people who were killed after water flooded subway cars in the capital Zhengzhou, which received a year's worth of rain in just three days.

3 million people have been affected by the catastrophe across the central Chinese province. See the latest at the link in our bio. (via @quicktake)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on July 21, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Bitcoin jumps after Musk says SpaceX ownsit, and Tesla mayacceptitagain again acceptit Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Tesla is "most likely" to resume accepting Bitcoin for purchases once mining becomes greener, Elon Musk said during a panel with high profile crypto backers.

Musk also revealed that, like Tesla, his space exploration company SpaceX holds the digital currency. And he told fellow panelists Cathie Wood and Jack Dorsey that he personally owns Bitcoin, Ethereum and Dogecoin. 

Bitcoin climbed as high as $32,820 during the discussion, after dipping below $30,000 earlier in the week. Full story at the link in bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on July 21, 2021. May be an image of text.

node.text:
The Tokyo Olympics is flipping investing wisdom on its head.

The Games are typically a boon for advertisers, real-estate firms and travel companies. But this year, with most people watching from home, market analysts are betting instead on Japan's fried-chicken chains, food-delivery operators and electronics stores selling TVs.

Sports apparel companies sponsoring athletes could also get a boost if teams rake in the medals. Click the link in bio to see analysts' stock picks.
